title: About
text: This is the lecture site for CSI 106

title: Getting Started
text:
Print
print() is an example of a function.

print("<- I am a function")

<- I am a function

title: Getting Started
text:
Help

help(print)

Help on built-in function print in module builtins:

print(*args, sep=' ', end='\n', file=None, flush=False)
    Prints the values to a stream, or to sys.stdout by default.

    sep
      string inserted between values, default a space.
    end
      string appended after the last value, default a newline.
    file
      a file-like object (stream); defaults to the current sys.stdout.
    flush
      whether to forcibly flush the stream.

title: Getting Started
text:
Or use AI
Open up gemini and have it explain.

title: Getting Started
text:
Arguments
Many functions take arguments
Some arguments are confusing
It help to play with new functions.

title: Getting Started
text:
Let’s play with print
Click here to be directed to github.com and open the code space to Hello World from Yesterday.
Let’s open a new python script.
Try these: 1. Set the variable message equal to a sentence and print it. 2. Change the sentence, but not the variable name and print it again. 3. Change end = “. 4. Can you change end to anything? 5. Make a variable equal to a number and print it and the message . 6. Change sep to”” with no space and print again.

title: Getting Started
text:
“\n” and “\t”
What do these do in print?
Make a some text that looks like this:


Top Step 
         Second Step 
                     Bottom Step

title: Getting Started
text:
New Functions
When you see new functions, be sure to ask for help()

title: Getting Started
text:
Variable Names
Pay attention when you are reading the text.
Name variables as they do in the text.

title: Getting Started
text:
Working in a terminal
If you do not see a terminal the
Go to Terminal > New Terminal

import this

The Zen of Python, by Tim Peters

Beautiful is better than ugly.
Explicit is better than implicit.
Simple is better than complex.
Complex is better than complicated.
Flat is better than nested.
Sparse is better than dense.
Readability counts.
Special cases aren't special enough to break the rules.
Although practicality beats purity.
Errors should never pass silently.
Unless explicitly silenced.
In the face of ambiguity, refuse the temptation to guess.
There should be one-- and preferably only one --obvious way to do it.
Although that way may not be obvious at first unless you're Dutch.
Now is better than never.
Although never is often better than *right* now.
If the implementation is hard to explain, it's a bad idea.
If the implementation is easy to explain, it may be a good idea.
Namespaces are one honking great idea -- let's do more of those!

title: Getting Started
text:
Comments
When working on code it is helpful to comment.
But don’t over comment.
Here’s the Style Guide for comments
Add a useful comment to your code above

title: Getting Started
text:
Psuedo Code
The general idea
We have a problem. We need to print a tic-tac-toe board.
With a partner discuss how this might be done.

title: Getting Started
text:
More Psuedo code
When playing tic-tac-toe we need the player to be able to input an X or an O without a mouse.

title: Getting Started
text: Pair programming

title: Getting Started
text:
Code it
On one computer try to code the tic-tac-toe board.
Consider your psuedocode.

One person types.
Both people talk to each other.

title: Getting Started
text:
Comment your code
After you have code that works (if it works)
Comment it.
Add a doc string to the top.
You may want to send the code via email (you could use git, but that’s getting tricky).

title: Getting Started
text:
Exercise 1
After you’ve got your tic-tac-toe board move on to exercise 1.
Note: Exercise 1 assumes your read chapters 1 and 2.
Here is exercise 1

title: Getting Started

First Day
Welcome to CSI 106
We will be coding from scratch. I assume that you all have little to no background in programming.

title: Getting Started
text:
About me
My name is Nicholas Schwab.
I’m studying Data Science as grad student at UT Austin.
I used to be in the Math Department here and lectured Data Science at Smith.
I like Rock Climbing and biking and hanging with my family.
I live in Easthampton.
My first programming language was R.

title: Getting Started
text:
Why CSI 106
You’ll learn to “think like a computer scientist”
You’ll build programs that are super neat and fun
You’ll develop the skills needed for industry.

Pablo Frank

title: Getting Started
text:
Why CS?
Learn to Plan:
How could you do these things:

Find which two people in the class share the most courses this semester.
Find the average number of classes taken this semester.
Sort students by number of classes taken.

Discuss with your peers.

title: Getting Started
text:
AI policy
In this class we will draft an AI policy together.
We will start this today.
We will use this document to develop our AI policy.

title: Getting Started
text:
Think Pair Share AI
I will now partner you up so you can share how you have used AI, and how you think you should use it in this class.
We will come back and draft some AI policy which we will revisit at the end of class and throughout the semester.

title: Getting Started
section: But AI can do almost everything?
text:
But AI can do almost everything?
Yes, but you wont learn if you use AI.
Everyone can now Vibe Code, you need to stand out.

Stand out with a portfolio
Stand out with induntry certifications
Stand out by knowing what you are talking about.

Let’s Vibe Code Gemini

title: Getting Started
text:
Complicated things

A human is still needed for new or complicated projects.
You will have to fix bugs in AI.
You will come across code that is complicated and will need to read/edit it.
We will see how AI has trouble during the semester.
If you work in a niche field AI will not necessarily be there to help.

I will try to convince you that AI is not your friend in this class.

title: Getting Started
text:

This class is long
We’ll have a break midclass.
Stand up stretch, get some water, look at your phone

Phones away in Class (after logging in).
